addressleaf.section: To the right honorable my very singular good Lord the Erle of Essex.

D
r
Birch's Memoirs Vol. 1 Page 291

page.lettertext:
fol.120r
May it please yo
r
good L. that point being
knowen, and told my by divers, of
e
Coronels
secret charge, astouching
e succo
r
w
ch
he must re-
quire, (albeit he himself doth conceale it alto-
gether) I thought it convenient to signifie so muche
unto my
L. T
re
r
, lest some other should prevent
me, to whome perhaps in like maner
e same intelli-
gence might be given. For I finde it is advertised
by divers out of
Scotland,
and namely from
S
r
William Keth
, and
M
r
Da[niel] Fowles
, to
e
Ligger
at
is heere, who this very day came of purpose to
tell me, that Stuart would communicat very litle
unto him, but bare him still in hand, that he had
very highe maters committed unto him by secret
instruction: and me thinkes, saied he, to drawe
some mony from
e states, he would put them in
head of I knowe not w
at
policie, as if in their
wisedom they were to take suche a course, as the
king might acknowledge, that w
at
soever great good
he shall attaine unto heereafter, commeth onely of
them and their assistance: and besides he pratled
muche of
e
Q. of England,
by way of extenuati
o
of her princely beneficence towardes
e
King,
w
t
many shiftes and devises to bring his purpose to
passe: in so muche as he told him, that if
e King
his master would be ruled by him, he should be
able to bridle both
e Queene and
e States, and
care for nether of bothe: but howe he meant it should be
done, he could not signifie directly, unles it
were by some accord w
t
e forfeited Lordes.
fol.120v
Moreover Stuart told him, that he was righte well
assured, that her Ma
tie
of purpose sent me hither to
demande
e remboursment of her monies, that it
might be a barre to his req
e
st: wherein he made no
doubt of obtaining his suite, if I had not come or had
not put in their headdes, that it behooved them to
deale w
t
her Hig
es
advise: w
ch
was too great an in-
dignitie to
e K. his master, that he should not use
the aide of his frindes, w
t
out
e privitie and liking
of
e Q. of England. And this
e Ligger
hath told me w
t
very special intreatie because
it touched him neere, that I would knowe it, and
not revele it, where his name might come in q
e
stion:
being very desirous, as by his speeches I could ga-
ther, to accommodat every mater between her Ma
tie
and his master. Upon this and
e rest
that I have written to yo
r
L. my last bearing date
the 2 and 4 of this moneth, I doe long very
muche to understand, somwhat from yow, howe
her Ma
tie
is affected, an d howe she will enjoine
me to tune my Voice in this songe.
And so I
take my humble leave. From
e Hage
Ma
r
14 1594.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
fol.121r
Sins the former was written, I was told by a
special frinde, who spake it upon knowledge, that
the K. of Scottes hath written a privat l
re
to
M
r
Barnevelt
w
t
his owne hand. And I am fully
persuaded, he hath done
e like to
M
r
Brederode
,
M
r
Valke
, and others: w
t
whome yo
r
L. may con-
sider w
at
force
e l
res
of that K. will have above
others, comming, as I assure my self they did, full
freighted w
t
fairer wordes, and kinde promises.
This art of writing to privat persons heere, is very
muche used by
e Frenche K. and hath bin one of
his chiefest meanes to c
o
passe his demandes, though
nowe and then they be remembred, w
t
some better
thing in hand to quicken their affections.
